Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: On Monday morning, a patient named Guernsey, male, middle-seventies was admitted to the hospital complaining of chest pains.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: He had been referred by a nursing home where the doctor had diagnosed his condition as angina pectoris. Now it is axiomatic that nursing home doctors are always wrong.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: The intern who admitted Mr. Guernsey, however, accepted the diagnosis and prescribed morphine, a drug suitable for angina but not at all suitable for emphysema, which is, unfortunately, what the old man actually had. Within an hour...

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: ...the patient became unresponsive and diaphoretic and was raced up to Intensive Care with an irregular pulse of 150, blood pressure 90 over 60, respiration rapid and shallow.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: The resident on duty now compounded the blunder by treating the old man for pulmonary edema. He gave him digitalis, diuretics and oxygen. This restored the old man's color...

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: ...and he was sent back to his room in the Holly Pavilion, ruddy complected and peacefully asleep.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: In point of fact, the patient was in CO2 narcosis...

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: ...and died at seven-thirty that evening.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: I mention all this, only to explain how the bed in Room 806 became available.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: The intern involved was a prickly young buck named Schaefer who had a good thing going for him with a technician in the hematology lab. In the haphazard fashion of hospital romances, Dr. Schaefer had been zapping this girl on wheelchairs, stretchers, pantry shelves...

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: ...in the kitchen, in the morgue, in the dark corners of corridors...

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: ...standing up, sitting down -- so you can imagine what an available bed meant to him.

Dialogue: No.

Dialogue: Maybe you ought to have a talk with Joe Einhorn.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I don't want to see a psychiatrist. Stop worrying about me. All I have to do is get my ass back to work, and I'll be fine. I'm sorry I've caused you concern.

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: Sid just called from St. Luke's, and he's heard that the demonstrators up there are planning a march to join the bunch down here.

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Oh, God.  Did you call the cops?

Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Oh boy.

Dialogue: What happened?

Dialogue: I've seen some pretty good snafus, but this one... I mean, there's a certain splendor to this one. One of the night nurses, a float, thought Schaefer was a patient and plugged an I.V. into him. He was a diabetic, you know.

Dialogue: What do you mean, a nurse plugged an I.V. into him?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Oh, it's really a screwed-up story, Doctor. You see, what happened was we had an old man in that bed who died last night, so the bed was available. And you know Schaefer. He's Sammy Stud.

Dialogue: And he talked a nurse into zapping him on that bed.

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: I think it was a girl from hematology he's been running with.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: My God, it's a Roman farce.

Dialogue: I thought I heard you out here, Doctor.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: As I understand it, one of the nurses inadvertently administered an I.V. to Schaefer here. How the hell could that happen?

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Listen, I think we ought to straighten this out somewhere else.

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: I suppose I'd better call the Medical Examiner.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I still don't know what happened.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I get the drift, Mrs. Christie. In other words, Nurse Perez went in and sedated Dr. Schaefer thinking it was the patient Guernsey. My God! What I don't understand...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: So she plugged an I.V. into him.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: A five percent glucose solution won't kill anybody. Did he have any other ancillary conditions? He wasn't dehydrated, was he? Speaker: bock
Dialogue: All right, wrap him up and get him down to Pathology. I'm especially interested in his blood sugar. A liter of glucose never killed anybody. Your ladies must've done something else to him.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Before you call the family, Doctor, I wish you'd talk to Mr. Mead about this. We'd like, naturally, to avoid litigation.

Speaker: miss lebow
Dialogue: Coffee?

Dialogue: A few things have been piling up. Would you like to go into them?

Speaker: miss lebow
Dialogue: A quickie. Dr. Esterhazy wants to start hiring temporary people to cover the summer vacations. He says last year some of the replacement people didn't receive their checks until they waited six months. He wonders if you could do something about getting these people paid more promptly.

Speaker: miss lebow
Dialogue: Now, as you know, Doctor, we've agreed to take over the local ambulance cases as part of the hospital's commitment to the community, and it's created a serious overload in the E.R. I don't know why this was dumped in our lap, but...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Find out if Dr. Einhorn is in his office yet.

Speaker: miss lebow
Dialogue: Which Dr. Einhorn? Ophthalmology or Psychiatry?

Dialogue: Psychiatry.  Never mind. I'll look in myself.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Is he in?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Can you give me a few minutes, Joe?

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I've been having periods of acute depression recently. Apparently, it's becoming noticeable. A number of people have remarked on it. Anyway, John Sundstrom thought it might be a good idea if I spoke to you about it.

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: Do you want to sit down, Herb?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: No. I'm not good at confessional.  Well, what can I tell you? The last year, two, three... it goes way back, I suppose. I can remember entertaining suicidal thoughts as a college student. At any rate, I've always found life demanding. I'm an only child of lower-middle-class people. I was the glory of my parents. My son the doctor. Well, you know. I was always top of my class. Scholarship to Harvard. The boy genius, the brilliant eccentric. Terrified of women, clumsy at sports. God, Joe, how the hell do I go about this?

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: I understand you just separated from your wife.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I left her a dozen times. She left me a dozen times. We stayed together through a process of attrition. Obviously sado-masochistic dependency. My home is hell. We've got a twenty- three-year-old boy I threw out of the house last year. A shaggy-haired Maoist. I don't know where he is, presumably building bombs in basements as an expression of his universal brotherhood. I've got a seventeen- year-old daughter who's had two abortions in two years and got arrested last week at a rock festival for pushing drugs. They let her off. The typical affluent American family. I don't mean to be facile about this.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I blame myself for those two useless young people. I never exercised parental authority. I'm no good at that. Oh, God, I'm no good at this either. Joe, let's just forget the whole thing. I'm sorry I bothered you.

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: How serious are your suicidal speculations, Herb?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I amuse myself with different ways of killing myself that don't look like suicide. I wouldn't want to do my family out of the insurance.

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: Digitalis will give you an arrhythmia.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: A good toxologist would find traces. Potassium's much better. Sixty milli equivalent. Instantaneous. Of course, then you're stuck with how to get rid of the hypodermic. Forty milli equivalent. Gives you plenty of time to dispose of the evidence.

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: You seem to have given considerable thought to the matter.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You ought to know a man who talks about it all the time never does it.

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: I don't know. I see a man who's exhausted, emotionally drained, riddled with guilt, and has been systematically stripping himself of his wife, children, friends, isolating himself from the world. Are you impotent?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Intermittently.

Speaker: einhorn
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: It means I haven't tried in so long, I don't know. Let's just drop the whole thing, Joe. I feel humiliated and stupid. All I have to do is pull myself together and get back into my work. I'm sorry I troubled you. Take care of yourself. I'll see you.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: All set?

Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Dialogue: Who's that exotic group?

Dialogue: Dr. Perry said he picked the tuberculosis and the liver nodes for today, right?

Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Dialogue: Good. Because that's the one I studied up. A hell of a case.

Dialogue: All right, who's presenting?

Dialogue: Give me that one again... thirty- two?

Dialogue: O.P.D. wants to know how that asthmatic they sent down is.

Dialogue: Will you leave that man alone?

Dialogue: Yeah?

Dialogue: Why don't we get together on this sometime this afternoon, Fran?

Dialogue: One o'clock will be fine.

Dialogue: What room is it?

Dialogue: For heaven's sake, Willie, you're going to be in the hospital for two lousy days. What're you making such a fuss about?

Dialogue: You're supposed to be such a big wheel here.

Dialogue: There are no private rooms available. If they brought in Jesus Christ fresh off the cross, I couldn't get Him a private room.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: I'm not going to stay in a room with a dying man...

Dialogue: He's not dying. They'll screen him off. You won't even know he's here.

Dialogue: If you want a private room, go on home, and I'll call you the first one that comes up. But you're the one who phoned me in a panic, you're going on a vacation. Dialogue: Well, you said it, he's a lunatic.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: Big wheel, can't even get me a private room.

Dialogue: I'll get you a tranquilizer...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Are you applying for your internship here?

Speaker: ambler
Dialogue: I'm not sure.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Come and see me.  Would you sit up for a minute?

Dialogue: We've got a little thing over here, Doctor. The girl over there is the daughter of the patient in Eight-O- Six. He is at the moment comatose and requires intravenous feeding and meds.

Speaker: brubaker

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: All right, wait a minute. Let me have all that again.

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, Doctor, this is Dr. Biegelman's case.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Never mind the professional ethics, what happened?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: The patient, a man of fifty-six, was admitted to the hospital ten days ago for a check-up, in good health, no visible distress. We did the mandatory work-up on him. I don't know how that sonofabitch in Farkis Pavilion ever found out about it. Maybe he had some kind of deal with one of the girls in the lab. Anyway, he turned up the next day, conned the patient into signing an authorization for a biopsy...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What sonofabitch in Farkis Pavilion?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Some post-grad fellow named Ives. Elroy Ives. I never met him. He's on one of the immunology research programs.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Are you trying to tell me some post- grad fellow came up here and did a biopsy on the patient?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Yes, sir. He conned Biegelman with that old story about...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: ...protein in the urine?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: And he biopsied the man?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: And he nicked a vessel, and at two o'clock in the morning, they woke up Biegelman because the nurse found the patient in shock. Biegelman called the kidney people for a consult right away. Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Welbeck?! That barber!

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: You ain't heard nothing yet. So we finally got Welbeck around four in the morning. He said, go ahead. So they laid on the surgery for eight. Welbeck turns up, half-stoned, orders an I.V.P., clears him for allergies...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: ...without actually testing.

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: And the patient went into shock...

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: ...and tubular necrosis. They lopped out the bleeding kidney, ran him back to the room, and we sat around waiting for three days to see how obstructed he was. Speaker: bock
Dialogue: In short, a man came into this hospital in perfectly good health, and, in the space of one week, we chopped out one kidney, damaged the other, reduced him to coma and damn near killed him.

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You know, Brubaker, last night I sat in my hotel room, reviewing the shambles of my life and contemplating suicide. Then I said "No, Bock, don't do it. You're a doctor, a healer. Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Hematology, sir.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: And now you come to me with this gothic horror story in which the entire machinery of modern medicine has apparently conspired to destroy one lousy patient. What was the name of that sonofabitch from Farkis Pavilion again?

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: Ives, sir. Elroy Ives. Somebody ought to ream his ass.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I'm going to ream his ass. And I'm going to break that barber Welbeck's back. I'm going to defrock those two cannibals. They won't practice in my hospital, I'll tell you that!

Speaker: brubaker
Dialogue: What'll I tell the girl, sir? She says we have no legal right to stop her from taking her father out. She's willing to sign an A.O.R. form.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Let him go. Before we kill him.

Dialogue: Get me Dr. Gilley. Put him on page if you have to. I want to talk to him right now. I don't care if he's operating.  And you get me some monkey named Ives. Ives. I-V-E-S, first name Elroy. He's in the Farkis Pavilion.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I want to talk to you, Joe. Would you mind coming into my office?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Have you got some punk named Ives rotating in your department?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I also want to know what the hell kind of a dialysis room you're running. I just came from...

Dialogue: Yeah... Gilley? Put him on. Bock. Didn't you tell me a couple of months ago you were going to cut off all privileges for that assassin, Welbeck? Yeah. Wellbeck. Dialogue: What do you mean, Ives is dead?

Dialogue: He had a heart attack in the Emergency Room?

Dialogue: Where is he now?

Dialogue: You don't find anything grotesque about all this?

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I mean, at half past eight this morning, we meet over a doctor who's been killed intravenously, and here we are again, four hours later, with another doctor who had a heart attack in the Emergency Room.

Dialogue: Well, what're you suggesting Doctor? Do you think we have a mad killer stalking the halls of the hospital? Presumably, Dr. Ives died of a heart attack and Schaefer in a diabetic coma. People do die of these things. It's all perhaps coincidental, but I don't think I'd call it grotesque.

Dialogue: How long are they going to be on Schaefer's post?

Dialogue: I don't suppose you'd like to call next of kin?

Dialogue: Oh God, I need a drink.

Dialogue: I mean that Indian's in there, half- naked and going pis-pis-pis with a little bag. You just better get in there, Mrs. Dunne.

Dialogue: Miss Drummond, are you still taking your father out?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Yes. I still have to arrange an ambulance service. Is there a phone around I could use?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Use my office.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Hello. I'd like to arrange an ambulance for one-thirty tomorrow afternoon... Thank you...

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: ...Drummond, first name, Barbara. I'll pay cash...

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: No, you're to pick up my father, Drummond, Edward, at the Manhattan Medical Center, Holly Pavilion, Room Eight-O-Six. It's a stretcher case. I presume you provide the stretcher.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: He's to be taken to American Airlines, Yes... No... Kennedy Airport, Flight Seven-Two-Nine to Yuma, Arizona. I'll accompany the patient... Yes, thank you.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You believe in witchcraft, Miss Drummond?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I believe in everything, Doctor.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Like a drink?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: It was not unusual to walk into our home and find my father sitting in his office, utterly serene and happily speaking to the air in this strange foreign tongue. I was, at that time twenty years old and having my obligatory affair with a minority group, in my case a Hopi Indian, a post-graduate fellow at Harvard doing his doctorate in the aboriginal languages of the Southwest. One day, I brought the Indian boy home just as my father was sinking to his knees in the entrance foyer in one of his trances. The Indian wheeled in his tracks and said, "Well, I'll be a sonofabitch." You see, my father was speaking an Apache dialect, an obscure dialect at that, spoken only by a ragged band of unreconstructed Indians who had rejected the reservation and were living in total isolation in the Sierra Madre Mountains of northern Mexico. Well! What do you say to that, Dr. Bock?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What the hell am I supposed to say to that, Miss Drummond?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I'm sitting here boozing and, all of a sudden, you start telling me some demented story about your father's religious conversion.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: No, no, you miss the point, Doctor. Not my father's conversion -- mine. You see, I had been hitting the acid pretty regularly at that time. I had achieved a few minor sensory deformities, some suicidal despairs, but nothing as wild as fluency in an obscure Apache dialect. I mean, like wow, man! I mean, here was living afflatus right before my eyes! Within a week, my father had closed his Beacon Hill practice and set out to start a mission in the Mexican mountains. And I turned in my S.D.S. card and my crash helmet and followed him. It was a disaster, at least for me. My father had received the revelation, not I. He stood gaunt on a mountain slope and preached the apocalypse to solemnly amused Indians. I masturbated a great deal. We lived in a grass wickiup and ate raw rabbit and crushed pion nuts. It was hideous. Within two months, I was back in Boston, a hollow shell and dizzy with dengue, disenchanted with everything. I turned to austerity, combed my hair tight and entered nursing school. I became haggard, driven and had shamelessly incestuous dreams about my father. I took up with some of the senior staff at the hospital. One of them, a portly psychiatrist, explained I was generated by an unresolved lust for my father. I apparently cracked up. One day, they found me walking to work naked and screaming obscenities. There was talk of institutionalizing me, so I packed a bag and went back to my father in the Sierra Madre Mountains. I've been there ever since. That's three years. My father is, of course, mad as a hatter. I watch over him and have been curiously content. You see, Doctor, I believe in everything.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Now what was that all about, Miss Drummond?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I thought I was obvious as hell. I'm trying to tell you I have a thing for middle-aged men.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I admire your candor.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: You've been admiring a lot more than that.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You're wasting your time. I've been impotent for years.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Rubbish.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Power to the Impotent! Right on, baby!

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Right on.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: When I say impotent, I don't mean merely limp. Disagreeable as it may be for a woman, a man may sometimes lust for other things, something less transient than an erection, some sense of permanent worth. That's what medicine was for me, my reason for being. When I was thirty-four, Miss Drummond, I presented a paper before the annual convention of the Society of Clinical Investigation that pioneered the whole goddam field of immunology. A breakthrough! I'm in all the textbooks. I happen to be an eminent man, Miss Drummond. And you want to know something, Miss Drummond? I don't give a goddam. When I say I'm impotent, I mean I've lost even my desire for work, which is a hell of a lot more primal a passion than sex. I've lost my raison d'etre, my purpose, the only thing I ever truly loved. It's all rubbish anyway. Transplants, antibodies, we manufacture genes, we can produce birth ectogenetically, we can practically clone people like carrots, and half the kids in this ghetto haven't even been inoculated for polio! We have assembled the most enormous medical establishment ever conceived, and people are sicker than ever! We cure nothing! We heal nothing! The whole goddam wretched world is strangulating in front of our eyes! That's what I mean when I say impotent! You don't know what the hell I'm talking about, do you?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Of course, I do.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I'm tired, I'm terribly tired, Miss Drummond. And I hurt, and I've got nothing going for me anymore. Can you understand that?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Yes, of course.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Then can you understand that the only admissable matter left is death?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Sounds to me like a familiar case of morbid menopause.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Oh Christ.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Well, it's hard for me to take your despair very seriously, Doctor. You obviously enjoy it so much.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Oh, bugger off. That's all I need now, clinical insights. Some cockamamie twenty-five-year-old...

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Twenty-seven.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: ...acidhead's going to reassure me about menopause now. Look, I'd like to be alone, so why don't you beat it? Close the door and turn off the lights on your way out.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Mr. Blacktree disapproves of my miniskirt, but it was the only thing I had to come to the city with. Back at the tribe, I wear ankle-length buckskin.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Swell. Just close the door and turn off the lights.

Speaker: barbara's voice
Dialogue: What're you shooting, Doc?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Leave me alone...

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Potassium. You take enough of this stuff, it'll kill you, Doc.  It occurred to me that I might have read you wrong, that you really were suicidal. So I came back.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Who the hell asked you!

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Who the hell asked you!

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Leave me alone! Why the hell don't you leave me alone!

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Why didn't you let me do it? Who the hell asked you!

Speaker: campanella
Dialogue: Well, I'll see you.

Speaker: campanella
Dialogue: Do you have a match, Doctor?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You wouldn't be awake.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: What time is it?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I swiped this for you out of the nurses' locker room. I'll make good on your dress. I'm afraid it's torn beyond repair. Buy yourself a new one or, if you like, give me your size and I'll send it on to you. But I want to talk to you about that.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Talk to me about what?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: About your father. You really shouldn't move him in his condition. I just had a look at his chart. There's no reason to presume brain damage. You know as well as I you can't predict anything in these instances. He could pull out of that coma at any time. I think you should let him stay here. I'll personally look after him.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Is this your way of saying you'd like me to stay in town a few more days?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Well, that would be nice, too.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What do you say, Miss Drummond?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I expect you can call me Barbara, considering you ravished me three times last night.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Three times?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Oh, look at him, pretending he didn't count. You were as puffed up as a toad about it. Punched a couple of holes in your crusade for universal impotence, didn't it? I think we're on a first name basis by now. I'll call you Herb.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Let's give your father a week, Barbara, what do you say?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I'm taking my father out of here -- and as quickly as I can.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You're a real fruitcake, you know?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Well, let me put it this way. I love you. I fancied you from the first moment you came lumbering down that hallway upstairs. I said to Mr. Blacktree, "Who's that hulking bear of a man?" The Apaches are reverential about bears. They won't eat bear meat; they never skin bears. Bear is thought of as both benign and evil, but very strong power. Men with bear power are highly respected and are frequently said to be great healers.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I said to Mr. Blacktree, "That man gets his power from the bear."

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Swell. Now, look, do you have a hotel, some sort of accommodations where you can stay for a week or so?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: All right, let me put it this way, Herb. My father and I accept the implacability of death. If he dies, he dies, but I'm taking him out of here and back to Mexico about one o'clock this afternoon. I want you to come with us, because I love you and want children.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I'm afraid Mexico sounds a little too remote for me.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: We could use you down there, you know. There's a curiously high incidence of T.B. And you'd be a doctor again, Herb. You'd be necessary again. If you love me, I don't see what other choice you have.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What do you mean, if I love you? I raped you in a suicidal rage. How did we get to love and children all of a sudden?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Oh, for heaven's sake, Herb, I ought to know if a man loves me or not. You must have told me half a hundred times last night you loved me. You murmured it, shouted it; one time, you opened the window and bellowed it out into the street.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I think those were more expressions of gratitude than love.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Gratitude for what?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Well, my God, for resurrecting feelings of life in me I thought dead.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Well, my God, what do you think love is?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Okay, I love you, and you love me. I'm not about to argue with so relentless a romantic. Well, then, since we have this great passion going for us, I don't see why you won't stay on here in New York for a week or ten days...

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: It's up to ten days now.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: As long as it takes for your father's condition to improve.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: No. I've had these prophetic dreams for seven nights. Seven is a sinister number. The meaning of these dreams is very clear, seven times as clear. I am to get my father and you out of this hospital before we are all destroyed.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You're certifiable! My God, half the time you're a perfectly intelligent young woman, and then suddenly you turn into a goddam cabalist who believes in dreams, witchcraft and bear power! And I don't like the way you dismiss my whole life as unnecessary. I do a lot of healing right here in Manhattan. I don't have to go to Mexico for it. I also teach. I send out eighty doctors a year into the world, sometimes inspirited, at least competent. I've built up one of the best damned departments of medicine in the world. We've got a hell of a heart unit here and a hell of a kidney group. A lot of people come into this hospital in big trouble, Miss Drummond, and go out better for the experience. So don't tell me how unnecessary I am.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: So how come, eight hours ago, you were trying to kill yourself with an overdose of potassium?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Where are you going now?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: My hotel. I have to check out. Mr. Blacktree doesn't speak any English.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Well, you're coming back, of course.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Of course. I have to settle the bill here and pack my father. And I think you need a few hours alone to make your decisions.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What decisions?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: You're a very tired and very damaged man. You've had a hideous marriage and I assume a few tacky affairs along the way. You're understandably reluctant to get involved again. And, on top of that, here I am with the preposterous idea you throw everything up and go off with me to some barren mountains of Mexico. It sounds utterly mad, I know. On the other hand, you obviously find this world as desolate as I do. You did try to kill yourself last night. So that's it, Herb. Either me and the mountains or the bottle of potassium. I'll be back in an hour or so. I'll be in my father's room.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: All right. I love you!  My God!

Speaker: police captain
Dialogue: I repeat. I'm asking you to come out peacefully. These buildings are condemned and unfit for habitation.

Speaker: police captain
Dialogue: You people are possessing this building illegally and in violation of the law. I'm asking you to come out peacefully...

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Goddammit, Barry, I've got a dozen community leaders waiting for me in the library! We've been trying to work out some kind of negotiable formula for two years! And with no help from you people in the Urban Affairs Division, I might add!

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: And I'm not going to throw all that down the drain because some cockamamie activist group is show-boating for the television cameras! You get those people out of those buildings before a wall collapses or a fire breaks out and we've got a riot on our hands!... Okay!

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Having your troubles, eh? Well, I won't take much of your time. My name's Welbeck. I've been associated with this hospital for six years, and, yesterday afternoon, Dr. Gilley called me to say he was cutting off my privileges at the hospital. Do you know anything about it?

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: It's news to me.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: He said he sent the report on.

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: I'll probably get it tomorrow. Report on what?

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Well, I'm not sure myself. I did a nephrectomy on a man about seven days ago. Emergency, called in at four in the morning. The man was hemorrhaging, he'd gone sour...

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Welbeck, I'm terribly sorry, but I do have this meeting.  In any event, there's nothing I can do about it. If Gilley wants to cut your privileges, he's Chief of Surgery, it's within his province. You'll have to have the hearing...

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: I have a laparotomy laid on for this morning. I assume I'll be allowed to go through with that.

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: I've been associated with this hospital for six years...

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Now, now, Welbeck. It seems to me I've had your name down here before for something...  I'll be in the staff room.

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Wait a minute. You're the fellow with the Medicaid collecting business who incorporated and went public, right? I mean, something like that? Milton Mead was telling me about you just the other day. You're a whole medical conglomerate. You've got a Factoring service, a computerized billing company, and a few proprietary hospitals, a few nursing homes. Good heavens, Welbeck, you shouldn't be brought up before a committee of mere doctors. You should be investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission. You'll have to go through with the hearing, Welbeck. I don't interfere in these things.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: ...no goddam halfway house, no way, baby! We ain't gonna wait 'til 1973 to deal with this problem! We want to kill the drug thing right now!... imperializing the Blackaporican community, and we reject the bourgie- ass middle-class black traitors and flunkies who are selling out the Blackaporican proletariat masses to the expansionist, racist policies of this shit hospital!...

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Let's get back to the abortion issue!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Sit down, Woman!

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: What the hell does the male establishment know about abortions?

Speaker: black woman
Dialogue: Who the hell raised the issue of birth control? The issue at hand is the control of drug addiction in this community and in the ghetto generally.

Speaker: black man
Dialogue: We don't want no goddam abortion...

Speaker: white doctor
Dialogue: Let's... let's get down to the core of this matter.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: The point is that this hospital is the landlord for those buildings and they should've turned them down.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Those buildings are imperialistic extensions of the medical establishment. This hospital ought to be rebuilding those tenements, give those people decent housing.

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Please, please, please!

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: You know, I hallucinated last night. I hallucinated there was an Indian doing a war dance in here.

Speaker: nurse chile
Dialogue: You weren't hallucinating, Mr. Mead. There was an Indian in here last night.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: There was?

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Dr. Norris says about half an hour.

Speaker: second nurse
Dialogue: Tell Shirley it was just an ovarian cyst.

Speaker: third nurse
Dialogue: Shirley, it was just an ovarian cyst!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Oh, thank God.

Speaker: orderly
Dialogue: William Mead from Holly Eight.

Speaker: circulating nurse
Dialogue: Number three, Marty.

Speaker: resident
Dialogue: It's legal for a doctor to incorporate in New York, isn't it, Doctor?

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: The really big money is in health leasing, of course. Dr. Hogan, the eminent orthopedic surgeon, and I incorporated a leasing company and went public last year. I hold a controlling interest in a number of proprietary hospitals, nursing homes and rest farms, and I've been leasing hospital equipment to my own hospitals at excessive rates. Why, you ask, am I draining my own hospitals? Well, my hospitals are taxed at 48 percent, and I'm giving my leasing company a hell of a price-earnings ratio, which'll balloon the market value of the stock. I hold three hundred thousand shares of that stock, lettered of course, but in a year, I'll dump those shares at a capital gain and walk off with a bundle...

Speaker: scrub nurse
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: resident anesthesiologist
Dialogue: There's no pulse, Doctor.

Speaker: resident anesthesiologist
Dialogue: There's no blood pressure, Doctor.

Speaker: resident
Dialogue: I can't feel a thing, sir.

Speaker: resident anesthesiologist
Dialogue: I did, sir.

Speaker: resident
Dialogue: She's just a young woman, sir. Do you think we should open the chest?

Speaker: resident
Dialogue: Bicarb?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Now, I don't want to get into an institutional hassle with you, Mrs. Christie. The malpractice here is monumental. As you see, Dr. Schaefer's blood sugar was twenty-three. No glucose solution is going to do that. The only thing that will do that is at least fifty units of insulin, probably more. The only presumption is that one of those nurses on the Eighth Floor shot fifty units of insulin into Schaefer's blood stream, either by injection or through the I.V., although how in God's name...

Speaker: miss mcguire
Dialogue: Doctor, did you ask the head nurse on the eighth floor to let you know when a Miss Drummond got there?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: miss mcguire
Dialogue: Well, she just got there.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: I better get Mr. Mead.

Speaker: black panther
Dialogue: ...abortion clinic! That's genocide, baby! You're just killing off blacks! We consider proliferation elemental to the class struggle!

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: ...for God's sake! We've got eleven people in these buildings, and we've got to get them out of there! We can rectify the injustices of the world tomorrow, but right now, for God's sake, can we get those people out of those buildings? Will you people please listen to me? Will you people please shut up and listen to me? Will you people please call a halt to this participatory democracy and address ourselves to the immediate problem?!

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: How long ago did this happen?

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: About half an hour.

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: Have you called the Medical Examiner?

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: Well, you'd better do that now. And you better call the precinct station house as well.

Speaker: circulating resident
Dialogue: Her chart says Mangafranni. Her bracelet says Mangafranni. The only thing that isn't Mangafranni is the woman.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Look, you're not going. I love you, and I'm not going to let you go.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Come on, let's start putting your father's things back. He's staying here.  I'll find an apartment somewhere. I'm staying in a filthy little hotel room. We can't use that.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I can't make it here, Herb. I'll crack up. I cracked up once already. One week here, and I'd be running naked through the streets screaming again. I can retain my sanity only in a simple society.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: For God's sake, Barbara, you can't seriously see me living in a grass shack hunting jackrabbits for dinner? Be sensible for God's sake.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I am being sensible. What is it you're so afraid of leaving here? Your plastic home? Your conditioned air? Your synthetic clothes? Your instant food? I'm offering you green silence and solitude, the natural order of things. Mostly, I'm offering me. I think we're beautiful, Herb.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You make it sound almost plausible.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I don't know why you even hesitate. What's holding you here? Is it your wife?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: No, that's all over. I suppose if I'm married to anything, it's this hospital. It's been my whole life. I just can't walk out on it as if it never mattered. I'm middle-class. Among us middle-class, love doesn't triumph over all. Responsibility does.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Herb, don't ask me to stay here with you, because I love you, and I will. And we'll both be destroyed.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I've got the bill here to pay yet.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I'll come with you.

Speaker: lagerman
Dialogue: Herb, you asked me to find that dialysis nurse.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What dialysis nurse?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: I'll go pay the bill.

Speaker: lagerman
Dialogue: The one who goofed on your patient, Drummond.

Speaker: lagerman
Dialogue: Well, her name is Theresa Campanella, but you are not going to believe this, Herb. She died on the operating table in O. R. Three about an hour ago.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What do you mean, she died on the operating table in O.R. Three?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You mean she was the one?

Speaker: lagerman
Dialogue: That's the one. I just identified her.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: What the hell's going on around here? Every time I try to find somebody in this hospital, they either died of a heart attack in Emergency or of anesthesia shock in an operating room.

Speaker: lagerman
Dialogue: Listen, I just came from the O.R. They're trying to find a Dr. Schaefer. Don't you have a kid named Schaefer in your service?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I had a Schaefer. He died yesterday of an overdose of insulin. What do they want Schaefer for?

Speaker: lagerman
Dialogue: The Holding Room nurse says there was a Dr. Schaefer hanging around the Holding Room. It wouldn't have been your Schaefer anyway. The nurse says it was senior staff, a middle- aged man.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: There's no senior staff named Schaefer in this hospital.

Speaker: lagerman
Dialogue: I told them that. I said, I don't know any senior staff around here named Schaefer. They've got detectives down there, everything. It's a whole big investigation.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I am the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca.

Speaker: barbara's voice
Dialogue: For heaven's sake, Dad! What the hell's going on?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: We all thought you were at Death's Door! What're you doing out of bed?

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: What happened? Did he say anything to you?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, he said, "I am the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca." And you'd better close the door, because if he's going to tell everyone who walks in here he's the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca, they'll put us all away. He's already killed two doctors and one nurse.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I am the wrath of the lamb and the angel of the bottomless pit.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: What do you mean he killed two doctors and a nurse?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I mean, he's killed two doctors and a nurse! And he just tried to kill me! He has something against doctors. Somehow he got hold of a thousand units of insulin and put it in Dr. Schaefer's intravenous solution. And somehow he got Dr. Ives to die of a heart attack in the middle of the Emergency Room. And somehow he got a dialysis nurse named Campanella to die of anesthesia shock on an operating table!  He's been running around the hospital wearing Dr. Schaefer's uniform. Right now, they're looking all over the place for this mysterious Dr. Schaefer. I know this all sounds as grotesque to you as it does to me, but you can see for yourself your father is not the helpless comatose patient we thought he was. Don't look at me like I'm the one who's crazy. Ask your crazy father!

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I was merely an instrument of God. I killed no one. They all three died by their own hands, ritual victims of their own institutions, murdered by irony, an eye for an eye, biblical retribution. Schaefer was first, you see, because he killed God. God was admitted to this hospital last Monday under the name of Guernsey...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I was instantly aware of a divine presence.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I was convinced this porcelain old man was, in fact, an Angel of the Lord...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: ...perhaps even Christ Himself.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: Our Savior was, it seems, suffering from emphysema.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: He was relentlessly subjected to the benefits of modern medicine. He was misdiagnosed, mismedicated, and put into shock by Dr. Schaefer; raced off to Intensive Care, where the resident compounded the blunder and induced a coma. I can tell you with authority that God is indeed dead. He died last Monday under the name of Guernsey.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: A few hours later, he appeared to me in a revelation.

Speaker: guernsey
Dialogue: Rise up, Drummond. You are dead, now you are restored.

Speaker: guernsey
Dialogue: Those who killed you and those who killed me will die in our place. You are the Paraclete of Caborca, the wrath of the lamb. The angel of the bottomless pit.

Speaker: guernsey
Dialogue: In this fashion has it been revealed to you.

Speaker: guernsey
Dialogue: The age is closed! The end is at hand! The seal is broken!

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: Well! Not quite the burning bush perhaps but prodigal enough for me. I was to avenge the death of God and my own brutalization. I was to kill Doctors Schaefer, Ives and Welbeck and the dialysis nurse Miss Campanella, whose negligence caused my coma.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I awaited a further sign from God, which was given to me later that evening. Dr. Schaefer, it seems, had arranged an assignation with a girl from the hematology lab named Sheila.

Speaker: schaefer
Dialogue: Hey Sheila, this is Howard, Sheila. Hey listen, I got us a bed for tonight. A real, honest-to-god bed.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: Boy, I sure hope nobody walks in.

Speaker: sheila
Dialogue: What's this in your pocket?

Dialogue: That's my insulin. Put it back.

Speaker: schaefer
Dialogue: It ain't contagious, don't worry about it.

Dialogue: And you put Schaefer's insulin into the I.V. jar.

Dialogue: Yes. And then a second nurse came and plugged the I.V. jar into Schaefer. God clearly intended a measure of irony here. The hospital was to do all the killing for me. All I need do was arrange for the doctors to become patients in their own hospital. Accordingly, the next morning, I set out for Dr. Ives. I put on Dr. Schaefer's uniform, pinched some digoxine from the pharmacy and a sandbag from a utility cart, and found my way to Dr. Ives' laboratory. I coshed him with the sandbag, gave him a massive shot of the digoxine. This, you see, brought on an instant condition of cardiac arrhythmia. When he came to, I brought him down to the Emergency Room.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: This is Dr. Ives. He's in the Nephrology Lab. I was in there a little while ago, and he was suddenly taken ill, and I thought I'd better get him over here right away.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: He had at that time perhaps an hour to live. Prompt treatment would have saved his life.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: As a staff doctor, he was seen without preliminaries...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: His vital signs were taken, an electrocardiogram...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: ...which revealed occasional ventricular premature contractions. An intern took his history...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: ...and then he was promptly...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: ...simply... forgotten to death. Simply mislaid...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: ...mislaid among the broken wrists, the chest pains, scalp lacerations, the man whose fingers were crushed in a taxi door, the infant with the skin rash, the child swiped by a car, the old lady mugged in the subway, the derelict beaten by sailors, the teenage suicide, the paranoids, drunks, asthmatics, the rapes, the septic abortions, the overdosed addicts...

Speaker: ambulance attendants
Dialogue: Not breathing! Not breathing!

Speaker: intern
Dialogue: Better put him in the Holding Room.

Speaker: miss aronovici
Dialogue: She's taking a little pulse.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: ...the fractures, infarcts, hemorrhages, concussions, boils, abrasions, the colonic cancers, the cardiac arrests -- the whole wounded madhouse of our times...

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: I wonder if I could have a minute of your time, Doctor...

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I am the fool for Christ and the Paraclete of Caborca.

Speaker: nameless man
Dialogue: Well, it's an honor and a privilege, Doctor. I've been here ten minutes, I can't seem to get anybody to help me. I'm suffering from some sort of amnesia. I can't remember my name. As a matter of fact, it's pretty screwy. I got mugged. Two hours ago, walking out of a coffee shop on Fifty- Seventh Street and Second Avenue, eight o'clock in the morning, broad daylight, I got mugged. A sixteen- year-old girl walks up to me, shows me a knife about a yard long and says, "Give me your wallet." I thought she was kidding. I mean there's hundreds of people walking right by. Well, she wasn't kidding. "Listen," I said, "all I got's about twenty bucks." So she takes the wallet anyway. So I said, "How about leaving me my identification?" I mean, I had my driver's license, my Diner's Club, my credit cards. But she took them all, the whole damn wallet, credit cards, everything. So I stopped some guy, I said, "Hey, you see that girl there, walking away?" He says, "Yeah." I said, "She just stole my wallet, credit cards and everything." He says, "Well, that's what they want, the credit cards." So I started looking for a cop. I mean, go find a cop, right? Well, I finally find a cop. The girl's halfway to South America by now, probably bought the ticket with my credit cards. So the cop says, "What's your name?" And you want to know something? I couldn't think of my name. The girl took all my identification, you know what I mean? She took all my credit cards. So I said, "You know this is screwy. I can't think of my name." So he took me to the station house. The sergeant says, "What's your name?" I said, "I don't know! She took all my credit cards!" So they took me down here. So what do you think, Doctor? I'm nuts, right? I finally flipped.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: In this way was it revealed to me the manner of Nurse Campanella's death. She was to die of the great American plague -- vestigial identity.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: So last night, I coshed Miss Campanella with a sandbag, sedated her with thorazine, shaved her, prepped her, and parked her in a corridor of the X-Ray Department for five hours.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Why X-Ray?

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: Well, at X-Ray, a sedated body lying around unattended for five hours wouldn't seem unusual.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: Her operation -- that is to say, Mrs. Mangafranni's operation -- was not scheduled until nine-thirty. So at nine-fifteen this morning, I rang for my nurse...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You rang for your nurse?

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: To insure one full hour of uninterrupted privacy.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Oh yes.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I got up, wheeled Miss Campanella off to the operating rooms, replaced her bed with Mrs. Mangafranni's, exchanged charts and identity bracelets. She died officially of anesthesia shock. But, in point of fact, she died because she was wearing another woman's identity.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: God, what do we do now? Let me take him back to Mexico. It's a simple world there. If you turn him in, they'll just cage him in the Rockland State Hospital for the Criminally Insane. Let me take him back, Herb.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Are you kidding? We'll both take him. I'm going with you! Get him dressed. We're getting out of here before the police put us all in Rockland State.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: I haven't finished my work here. I have this Welbeck to dispose of. I am the angel of the bottomless pit and the wrath of the lamb.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Oh dear, he's having another revelation.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Look, that ambulance must be here by now. You go down and get them. I'll give him a shot of something to knock him out. We'll take him to the airport in the ambulance.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: You're hallucinating again.

Speaker: mead
Dialogue: We'll be in Eight-O-Six.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: I'm Dr. Welbeck. I have a patient on this floor named Drummond, and I'd like to see his chart.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Oh, Dr. Bock. Can I have a few minutes of your time, sir?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Dr. Gilley tells me you're the one who initiated these proceedings against me.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I'm busy, Welbeck.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: I'd like to know what you have against me.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: You turned up half-stoned for a simple nephrectomy eight days ago, botched it, put the patient into failure and damn near killed him. Then, pausing only to send in your bill, you flew off on the wings of man to an island of sun in Montego Bay. This is the third time in two years we've had to patch up your patients; the other two died. You're greedy, unfeeling, inept, indifferent, self-inflating and unconscionably profitable. Aside from that, I have nothing against you. I'm sure you play a hell of a game of golf. What else do you want to know?

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Excuse me for a moment, Doctor.  Hello, Arthur, I understand you've been trying to reach me all morning...

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: I'm telling you, Milton, he pulls out all the wires and the tubes, and he gets up and puts on a doctor's uniform, and he goes out, and he murders doctors! He just went out ten seconds before you came in!

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: And I'll tell you something else about this crazy place you got here! There was a naked Indian in here last night doing a war dance! That's the kind of crazy place you're running here, Milton! You got to get me out of here, Milton. This is a crazy place, Milton!

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: I wake up last night, there's a goddam Indian in here, a naked Indian! What kind of hospital is this?

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: This is Mr. Mead, are you paging me?

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: A couple of hours later I wake up again, and the guy in that bed there is getting out of the bed...

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: Are the police still in the building?

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: You'd better get them up here. Yes.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: All day long, he lays there like a dead man. All of a sudden, in the middle of the night, he gets out of bed! I thought I was going crazy!

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: Yes, this is Mead... Oh, dear. When?...

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: You know what he says to me? He says, you're hallucinating. Listen, I just saw a naked Indian. Now, I'm seeing a ghost. I got to figure he's right, I'm hallucinating, right?

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: I'll be down directly.  I'm sure you're wondering what this is all about, Herb.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: You're not going to leave me alone in this crazy place, Milton!

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: You better call the cops, Tom.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: Milton! Milton! Milton!!!

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: I haven't the time now, and I'm not even going to try to tell you this curious story my brother just told me. I'll fill you in on it at lunch some time.

Speaker: milton mead
Dialogue: Hold it!

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: The ambulance is here.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Yeah, but your father isn't. He's disappeared. He put on Schaefer's uniform and has gone out to do God's work, presumably the murder of Dr. Welbeck. Except, that fellow on the phone over there is Dr. Welbeck.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Oh my God, Arthur! What are you talking about? Have you talked to Dr. Hogan about this?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: And, on top of everything else, the other patient in your father's room overheard his whole confession and just told the Chief Administrator of the hospital. They're sending for the cops.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Oh, my God, Arthur. Well, who held title? Do the underwriters know about this yet?... Oh my God! Arthur, what're you waiting for? Arrest the son of a bitch! Turn him in!... Oh my God! When?... Of course, Arthur, call me right back. I'm at the Holly Pavilion, Eighth Floor. Please! Right away!

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Are you all right, Welbeck?

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: All right?! That son of a bitch is trying to wipe me out! My partner, the eminent orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Noel Hogan, is a miserable thief. And he's trying to wipe me out!

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: What room is it?

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: I'm expecting a phone call. Put it straight through to me in that room.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: The son of a bitch has been draining the company with phony purchase orders on another company, of which, it now turns out, his wife is the principal stockholder! Transparent fraud! I'll send him up for twenty years!

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Well, Drummond, you don't seem that much the worse for the wear.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Would you mind using some other phone? I'm expecting an important call.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: What is this? Who... who is this guy?

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Yes, well, I'll be at the Nurses' Desk, Sergeant. It would be futile for me to try to explain this to you over the phone.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: You've got a bit of fever, Drummond, but you're coming along very well.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: I'm not Drummond, you monkey! Drummond's the other bed!

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: That's mine.  It's Welbeck here... Yes, Arthur, go ahead...

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: I'm getting out of this nuthouse!

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: All right, take it easy, Mr. Mead.

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: I came in here just to get a lousy polyp cut out.

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: Oh, my God, what do you mean? How many transactions were there? Bu... but Arthur, I... I borrowed against that stock! I'm in the hole for over three hundred thousand!...

Speaker: william mead
Dialogue: I'm a sick man! I'm supposed to have peace and quiet!

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: What do you mean, Brazil?! I just spoke to Hogan's office yesterday, and they just told me...

Speaker: welbeck
Dialogue: I'm wiped out. The S.E.C. has suspended trading in my stock!

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Cardiac arrest, Holly Eight.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: We have an emergency here.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Breathe him.

Dialogue: He went to lunch.

Dialogue: Give him an ambu bag and an airway.

Dialogue: What's been happening?

Dialogue: Watch it...

Dialogue: Who is it?

Dialogue: One of the patients had a cardiac arrest.

Dialogue: Total cardiac arrest.

Dialogue: About a minute. No pulse, no heartbeat, no respiration...

Dialogue: Endotrachial tube.

Dialogue: I'm sorry, Doctor, but we have another

Speaker: chandler
Dialogue: Endotrachial tube.

Dialogue: Yes, his name's Drummond. That's his chart.

Dialogue: Was it Drummond?

Dialogue: That's two hundred.

Dialogue: What do we do now?

Dialogue: It's four hundred.

Dialogue: Let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, for the age is closed, the season of the seventh seal is at hand!

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Is he dead?

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: They can't get him out of fib. I don't think he'll make it.

Speaker: hitchcock
Dialogue: Thank God.  This should close the case, Sergeant.

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Everybody take it easy! Nobody's going to be hurt! We just want the Director!

Speaker: shouting crowd
Dialogue: We want Sundstrom! We want Sundstrom! Community control! Community control! Hip-hip-Hippocrates! Up with service! Down with fees!

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: You people want to see me?

Speaker: first militant
Dialogue: Yeah, baby, we want to see you...

Speaker: second militant
Dialogue: We're taking over this hospital, man...

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: I've had it up to here. I'm not dealing with this kind of cheap blackmail!

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Now look, man. Now wait a minute there!

Speaker: first militant
Dialogue: We're looking for a hostage!

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Fourteen people just got arrested for doing...

Dialogue: Lookit, man, where's the TV camera?

Dialogue: Would you be cool, man?  Fourteen people got arrested for doing nothing but living in their homes, which you people threw them out of.

Dialogue: Right on!

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: So now we're going to arrest you. We're going to hold you hostage and we ain't letting you go un...

Dialogue: We, the members of the Doctors Liberation Committee indict this hospital for the criminal neglect of the community in which it is situated! We demand an immediate dissolution of the governing and executive boards.

Speaker: shout
Dialogue: What are you going to do about those fourteen ghetto people?

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: I am not going to do anything... about anything.

Speaker: shout
Dialogue: Yes, you are!

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: By God, if you want to take over this hospital, you take it over!

Speaker: shouts
Dialogue: We will! Right on!

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: You run it! I am finished! I quit! You run it! You pay the bills! You fight the city!

Speaker: militant
Dialogue: We will!

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: You fight the state! You fight the unions. You fight the community! You... you think you can do a better job, you do it! Now I am finished! I quit! It's all yours!

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Quit! Quit!

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: Let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, for the age is closed, the season of the seventh seal is at hand! The age is closed! The season of the seventh se...

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: Dr. Welbeck is dead. They thought he was you.

Speaker: drummond
Dialogue: Yes, I know. We must arrange to have his body shipped to my Apache village where we will bury him with full tribal rites. In a day or two, somebody'll ask, "Whatever happened to Dr. Welbeck?" And it will be assumed he absconded to Brazil to join his partner, the eminent orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Noel Hogan. Welbeck, too, was mislaid, overlooked, forgotten to death, you see.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: We have to hurry, Dad.

Speaker: bock
Dialogue: I'm not going.  Kennedy Airport. You've got a two- thirty flight to make.

Dialogue: You going back in?

Speaker: sundstrom
Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: It's like pissing in the wind, right, Herb?
